edge: Nolan used this screening to make a case for the continued use of film, feeling that its superior image quality was being phased out due to the introduction of digital formats.

Nolan invited several prominent directors, including Edgar Wright, Michael Bay, Bryan Singer, Jon Favreau, Eli Roth, Duncan Jones and Stephen Daldry, to Universal CityWalk's IMAX theatre for a private screening of The Dark Knight Rises.

Nolan explained that he wanted to give the prominent directors a chance to see the potential of film, as he felt that unless they continued to assert their choice to use film in their productions, they may eventually lose it as an option.
Nolan stated that IMAX is the gold standard and what any other technology has to match up to, but none have, in his opinion.

The base layer of the Batsuit is made of a polyester mesh that is utilized by the military and high-tech sports manufacturers because of its breathability and moisture-wicking properties.
Molded pieces of flexible urethane were then attached to the mesh, to form the overall body armor plating.
Carbon fiber panels were placed inside the sections on the legs, chest and abdomen of the Batsuit.
The cowl was sculpted from a cast of Bale's face and head to become a perfect fit for Christian Bale.
Two layers of material were used in creating Selina Kyle's catsuit, the outer layer being polyurethane-coated spandex embossed with a hexagonal pattern.

The Dark Knight Rises is an ambitious, thoughtful, and potent action film that concludes Christopher Nolan's franchise in spectacular fashion.
Audience gave the film an average grade of 'A' on an A+ to F scale.

Phil Villarreal from OK! Magazine gave the film a rating of 1.5 out of 4, saying 'It's this series' version of The Matrix Revolutions, The Godfather Part III or Caddyshack 2.' However, in contrast, Todd Gilchrist from The Playlists called it 'a cinematic, cultural and personal triumph, emotionally inspiring, aesthetically significant and critically important for America itself – as a mirror of both sober reflection and resilient hope.'

Writing in Salon, David Sirota compared The Dark Knight Rises to popular culture reflecting the political period of the time and accused it of perpetuating a conservative agenda. This supposed conservatism was also noted by Occupy Wall Street leader David Graeber who stated that the film 'really is a piece of anti-Occupy propaganda'.

Writing in Salon, David Sirota compared The Dark Knight Rises and the game Call of Duty to 1980s popular culture reflecting the political period of the time and accused them of perpetuating a conservative agenda.
Chuck Dixon, the cocreator of the Bane character, said that Bane is 'far more akin to an Occupy Wall Street type if you're looking to cast him politically.'

In this film, Bane takes extreme measures to eliminate the wealthy class, which is seen as excessive and unnecessary by liberal commentator Jonathan Chait. This contrasts with Catherine Shoard's viewpoint that the film promotes a 'radically conservative' stance, advocating for championing the wishes of the wealthy if they claim to want to do good.
Christian Bale was amazed that the script had 'foreseen' the Occupy movement, highlighting the similarity between Bane's actions and those of real-life occupiers.
Nolan denied that the film criticizes the Occupy movement, indicating that he did not intend for any of his Batman films to be political.
Nolan stated that the film would result in wildly different interpretations regarding whether it supported or did not support the Occupy Wall Street movement.
Nolan clarified that the film was not intended to be a criticism of the Occupy movement.
